elements.content: A Cu(II) connected V4O16-cubane based metal organic framework, Cu2(phen)2(V4O8)(PO4)4 [Cu2V4O16-2D] was synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. This is the first example of transition metal connected V4O16-cubane based MOF. X-ray single crystal data shows the alternate arrangement V4O16-cubane and Cu(phen)(O)3 square pyramidal unit in two dimensions. These two-dimensional sheets are stacked on top of each other to form a three-dimensional architecture. Cu2V4O16-2D shows two types of solid state morphologies of the same phase, which was confirmed by scanning electron microscopy. It is noteworthy that this type of morphological difference of the solid phase in an extended metal–organic hybrid material is rare and has not been perceived in the polyoxovanadate based MOFs literature. Cu2V4O16-2D was further characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), IR-spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and elemental analysis. We also studied the static magnetic and gas adsorption properties for Cu2V4O16-2D.
elements.clean_text: A Cu(II) connected V4O16-cubane based metal organic framework, Cu2(phen)2(V4O8)(PO4)4 [Cu2V4O16-2D] was synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. This is the first example of transition metal connected V4O16-cubane based MOF. X-ray single crystal data shows the alternate arrangement V4O16-cubane and Cu(phen)(O)3 square pyramidal unit in two dimensions. These two-dimensional sheets are stacked on top of each other to form a three-dimensional architecture. Cu2V4O16-2D shows two types of solid state morphologies of the same phase, which was confirmed by scanning electron microscopy. It is noteworthy that this type of morphological difference of the solid phase in an extended metal-organic hybrid material is rare and has not been perceived in the polyoxovanadate based MOFs literature. Cu2V4O16-2D was further characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), IR-spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and elemental analysis. We also studied the static magnetic and gas adsorption properties for Cu2V4O16-2D.

elements.content: Cu2V4O16-2D is the first example of a transition metal connected V4O16-cubane based metal organic framework which was synthesized using a hydrothermal method. The bulk phase of Cu2V4O16-2D shows two different (flower and needle) types of morphology. The flower-like morphology (minor) could be an intermediate en route to the needle-like crystal form.
elements.clean_text: Cu2V4O16-2D is the first example of a transition metal connected V4O16-cubane based metal organic framework which was synthesized using a hydrothermal method. The bulk phase of Cu2V4O16-2D shows two different (flower and needle) types of morphology. The flower-like morphology (minor) could be an intermediate en route to the needle-like crystal form.

elements.content: Polyoxometalates (POMs) are an accumulation of transition metals (mainly vanadium, molybdenum, tungsten) and oxide clusters with high negative charge. POMs have diverse application in the fields of catalysis, electrochemistry, photochemistry, magnetochemistry, and medicine. It is noteworthy that polyoxometalates have the potential to join metal ions via their peripheral oxygen atoms to form network structures. Research on network structures, especially metal organic frameworks (MOFs), has picked up immense attention due to their versatile applications in gas storage, sequestration, catalysis, drug delivery, etc. Recently, researchers attempted to introduce POMs inside the MOFs. POM incorporated MOFs not only introduce functionality inside the structure but also enhance the thermal stability of the network. Owing to these facts, researchers have become interested in the design and synthesis of new MOFs composed of transition-metal complexes (TMCs) as well as polyoxometalates (POMs) to produce TMC-linked POMs.
elements.clean_text: Polyoxometalates (POMs) are an accumulation of transition metals (mainly vanadium, molybdenum, tungsten) and oxide clusters with high negative charge. POMs have diverse application in the fields of catalysis, electrochemistry, photochemistry, magnetochemistry, and medicine. It is noteworthy that polyoxometalates have the potential to join metal ions via their peripheral oxygen atoms to form network structures. Research on network structures, especially metal organic frameworks (MOFs), has picked up immense attention due to their versatile applications in gas storage, sequestration, catalysis, drug delivery, etc. Recently, researchers attempted to introduce POMs inside the MOFs. POM incorporated MOFs not only introduce functionality inside the structure but also enhance the thermal stability of the network. Owing to these facts, researchers have become interested in the design and synthesis of new MOFs composed of transition-metal complexes (TMCs) as well as polyoxometalates (POMs) to produce TMC-linked POMs.

elements.content: Polyoxovanadates (POVs) are an important class of polyoxometalates which has a unique ability to adopt different coordination geometries, such as tetrahedral, square-pyramidal, and octahedral. As vanadium can form POMs with IV and V oxidation states, POVs could be used in catalysis. The catalytic reactions of POVs are influenced by the facile change of oxidation states of the vanadium centers. However, successful design and synthesis of desirable MOFs with existing POVs are still challenging. The extended structure or supramolecular assembly with abundant POVs such as decavanadate is reported, but the extended structure with small POVs such as the V4O16 unit will enrich the probability of synthesizing different types of POV hybrid based materials with the desired architectures and properties. Here, we report the synthesis and structural study of two-dimensional transition-metal complexes (TMC) linked, V4O16 cubane based MOF structures formulated as Cu2(phen)2(V4O8)(PO4)4 [Cu2V4O16-2D]. Although there have been reports of V4O16 cubane and V4O12 boat type POVs based structures in the literature, the V4O16 cubane structure that we have reported in this paper is very rare and, to the best of our knowledge, the first report of the TMC connected V4O16 cubane based MOF architecture.
elements.clean_text: Polyoxovanadates (POVs) are an important class of polyoxometalates which has a unique ability to adopt different coordination geometries, such as tetrahedral, square-pyramidal, and octahedral. As vanadium can form POMs with IV and V oxidation states, POVs could be used in catalysis. The catalytic reactions of POVs are influenced by the facile change of oxidation states of the vanadium centers. However, successful design and synthesis of desirable MOFs with existing POVs are still challenging. The extended structure or supramolecular assembly with abundant POVs such as decavanadate is reported, but the extended structure with small POVs such as the V4O16 unit will enrich the probability of synthesizing different types of POV hybrid based materials with the desired architectures and properties. Here, we report the synthesis and structural study of two-dimensional transition-metal complexes (TMC) linked, V4O16 cubane based MOF structures formulated as Cu2(phen)2(V4O8)(PO4)4 [Cu2V4O16-2D]. Although there have been reports of V4O16 cubane and V4O12 boat type POVs based structures in the literature, the V4O16 cubane structure that we have reported in this paper is very rare and, to the best of our knowledge, the first report of the TMC connected V4O16 cubane based MOF architecture.

elements.content: As part of ongoing investigations of different synthetic approaches, the hydrothermal method became the most efficient method for the synthesis of MOFs. A one-pot synthesis of this type, where four/five inhomogeneous phases were used as precursor to get only one phase of pure product, is possible only under hydrothermal conditions. The most probable reason could be the high temperature and pressure generated during reaction, which favor the inhomogeneous phases (organic and inorganic) mixing together. The Cu2V4O16-2D MOF was synthesized under hydrothermal conditions by heating the mixture of Na3VO4 (0.49 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·xH2O (0.13 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (0.08 mmol), and 0.5 mL of concentrated H3PO4 in 5 mL of water (pH ≅ 2.10–2.40) at 150 °C for 96 h and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), IR-spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and elemental analysis (EA).
elements.clean_text: As part of ongoing investigations of different synthetic approaches, the hydrothermal method became the most efficient method for the synthesis of MOFs. A one-pot synthesis of this type, where four/five inhomogeneous phases were used as precursor to get only one phase of pure product, is possible only under hydrothermal conditions. The most probable reason could be the high temperature and pressure generated during reaction, which favor the inhomogeneous phases (organic and inorganic) mixing together. The Cu2V4O16-2D MOF was synthesized under hydrothermal conditions by heating the mixture of Na3VO4 (0.49 mmol), Cu(NO3)2⋅xH2O (0.13 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (0.08 mmol), and 0.5 mL of concentrated H3PO4 in 5 mL of water (pH ≅ 2.10-2.40) at 150 °C for 96 h and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), IR-spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and elemental analysis (EA).

elements.content: Different types of tetravanadate units are reported in the literature, such as V4O12, V4O16, and V4O18 (Table S4 in the ). V4O12 has a planar kind of arrangement with all tetrahedral vanadium centers, and among the V4O16 units there are two kinds of clusters: V4-boat and V4-cubane (Figure S18). There are few reports of V4-boat, but V4-cubane is very rare. In both types of V4O16 units, all the vanadium centers are octahedral. We can visualize these types of V4-cubane and V4-boat units in most abundant V10O28 clusters (Figure S20). But separately getting these types of V4-units is very difficult; they generally self-assemble to grow as larger clusters. This work is one of the rare attempts to isolate V4O16 cubane as a 2-D sheet.
elements.clean_text: Different types of tetravanadate units are reported in the literature, such as V4O12, V4O16, and V4O18 (Table S4 in the ). V4O12 has a planar kind of arrangement with all tetrahedral vanadium centers, and among the V4O16 units there are two kinds of clusters: V4-boat and V4-cubane (Figure S18). There are few reports of V4-boat, but V4-cubane is very rare. In both types of V4O16 units, all the vanadium centers are octahedral. We can visualize these types of V4-cubane and V4-boat units in most abundant V10O28 clusters (Figure S20). But separately getting these types of V4-units is very difficult; they generally self-assemble to grow as larger clusters. This work is one of the rare attempts to isolate V4O16 cubane as a 2-D sheet.

elements.content: Cu2V4O16-2D crystallizes in the triclinic (P1̅ space group) crystal system. The asymmetric unit contains four distorted VO6 octahedra, two distorted Cu(phen)(O)3 square pyramidal units, and four phosphate groups. In each VO6 octahedra, the V–Obridging, V–Ophosphate, and V–Oterminal bond distances are 1.865(3), 1.896(3), and 1.593(3) Å, respectively. The Cu(phen)(O)3 square pyramidal unit consist of two equatorial Cu–O bonds [1.896(3) Å and 1.948(3) Å] and one axial Cu–O bond [2.390(3) Å]. The average Cu–N bond distances in the Cu(phen)(O)3 unit lie between 1.997(3) and 2.017(3) Å. Four such VO6 octahedra are packed together to form one V4O8 cubane unit. Each VO6 octahedron is edge shared; four μ3-oxygen atoms connect four octahedra together to form a cubane-like architecture (Figure a). Inside the cubane, the V–O–V and O–V–O bond angles vary from ∼78° to 102°, creating the structural distortion from perfect cubane. Each V4O8 cubane is connected to four different Cu(phen)(O)3 square pyramidal units (Figure b). One V4O8 cubane is connected to two V4O8 cubanes via a PO4 group through the crystallographic a-axis; the same V4O8 cubane is connected to two other V4O8 cubanes via two PO4–Cu–PO4 units through the crystallographic b-axis. A square pyramidal Cu(II) is connected to each V4O8 unit via an axial Cu–O bond. The “V–O–P–O–V” connectivity in the a-axis and the “V–O–P–O–Cu–O–P–O–V” connectivity in the b-axis create a 2D sheetlike architecture that propagates along the ab-plane (Figure c). These 2D sheets are interdigitated via phenanthroline rings which are coordinated with coppers. The closest distance between two interdigitated phenanthroline rings is 3.577 Å, and the closest distance between two vanadium layers is 10.218 Å (Figure d). The difference of the Cu2V4O16-2D structure from the earlier phosphate connected V4O8 cubane structure, (C10H10N2){(VO2)4(PO4)2} (where C10H10N2 = 4,4-bipyridinium cation), is that, in the reported structure, cubanes were connected via a PO4 group in both directions and there were no Cu(II) atoms in the structure to form a TMC-POM based MOF, whereas, in Cu2V4O16-2D, through the a-axis, connectivity was via PO4 and, through the b-axis, V4O16 cubanes are connected via PO4–Cu–PO4 units and the resulting structure is a TMC-POM based MOF.
elements.clean_text: Cu2V4O16-2D crystallizes in the triclinic (P1̅ space group) crystal system. The asymmetric unit contains four distorted VO6 octahedra, two distorted Cu(phen)(O)3 square pyramidal units, and four phosphate groups. In each VO6 octahedra, the V-Obridging, V-Ophosphate, and V-Oterminal bond distances are 1.865(3), 1.896(3), and 1.593(3) Å, respectively. The Cu(phen)(O)3 square pyramidal unit consist of two equatorial Cu-O bonds [1.896(3) Å and 1.948(3) Å] and one axial Cu-O bond [2.390(3) Å]. The average Cu-N bond distances in the Cu(phen)(O)3 unit lie between 1.997(3) and 2.017(3) Å. Four such VO6 octahedra are packed together to form one V4O8 cubane unit. elements.content: (a) Schematic and ball–stick models of the V4O16 unit. (b) One V4O16 cubane connected to four phosphates and four Cu(II) square-pyramid units. (c) 2-D arrangement of Cu2V4O16-2D, where one V4-cubane is connected to the next V4-cubane via one phsophate group through the a-axis and via two phosphates and two Cu(II) units through the b-axis. (d) Interdigitation of 2-D sheets of Cu2V4O16-2D via the phenanthroline ring in the ac-plane. [Color code: black, C; green, Cu; red, O; blue, N; yellow, P; dark yellow, V.]
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Schematic and ball-stick models of the V4O16 unit. (b) One V4O16 cubane connected to four phosphates and four Cu(II) square-pyramid units. (c) 2-D arrangement of Cu2V4O16-2D, where one V4-cubane is connected to the next V4-cubane via one phsophate group through the a-axis and via two phosphates and two Cu(II) units through the b-axis. (d) Interdigitation of 2-D sheets of Cu2V4O16-2D via the phenanthroline ring in the ac-plane. [Color code: black, C; green, Cu; red, O; blue, N; yellow, P; dark yellow, V.]

elements.content: The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) data collected for as synthesized Cu2V4O16-2D reveals an unusual morphological difference of the bulk material. The major portion of the compound consists of needle shaped crystals (150–200 μm in length and 2–6 μm width), one of the best of which was used for X-ray crystal data collection. We surprisingly found few flower-like morphologies along with the needle-like crystal in the SEM images, which are composed of several fine plates (Figure ). The fine plates could be a supramolecular assembly of a few Cu2V4O16-2D sheets, which stack on top of each other via π–π interaction to form flakes of flower type morphology. These flakes further grow with time in three dimensions into needle shaped crystals. The PXRD data (there is no significant difference in the experimental PXRD as compared to the simulated one, Figure a) and IR-spectra (Figure b) support the presence of only one phase, which was identified by crystal structure. Therefore, the flower type of morphology could be an intermediate stage of crystallization which is en route toward the needle-like crystal form of the same MOF. It is noteworthy that this type of morphological difference of the solid phase in extended metal–organic hybrid material is rare and has not been perceived in the POV based MOFs literature. All major peaks of experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of Cu2V4O16-2D match well with simulated PXRD, indicating their reasonable crystalline phase purity. The strong bands at 916 (band 4) and 965 cm–1 (band 5) in the IR spectrum are due to the typical stretching vibrational mode of terminal VO double bonds. The bands at 1036 cm–1 (band 6) are assigned to the PO4 antisymmetric stretching vibrational modes, and the band at 839 cm–1 (band 3) could be attributed to the related PO4 symmetric stretching modes. The peaks in the 643 (band 1) and 718 (band 2) cm–1 regions are also associated with V–O–V stretching vibrational modes, and several intense bands between 1200 and 1650 cm–1 arise from the presence of copper coordinated phenanthroline rings inside the structure. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on as-synthesized Cu2V4O16-2D in order to understand the thermal stability of the MOF with respect to temperature. The decomposition point at ∼325 °C indicates the high thermal stability of the MOF (Figure b). Gas adsorption in POM based hybrid materials is rare. We have shown in our earlier work that POM based ionic salts could be used as H2 and CO2 storage materials. The as-synthesized sample of Cu2V4O16-2D was immersed in dry chloroform at ambient temperature for 72 h, evacuated at ambient temperature for 24 h, and then evacuated at an elevated temperature (85 °C) for 48 h. The sample thus obtained was optimally evacuated, as evidenced by their well-maintained PXRD patterns and the long plateau (ambient temperature to 300 °C) in their TGA traces. The H2 adsorption isotherm exhibits type-II sorption behavior. At 760 Torr and 77 K, Cu2V4O16-2D adsorbs 0.37 wt % H2. The framework of Cu2V4O16-2D exhibits a typical type-II profile for CO2 (3.4 Å) adsorption. Cu2V4O16-2D adsorbs 1.01 mmol/g of CO2 at 298 K and 1 bar pressure (Figure c).

elements.content: (a) SEM image of the bulk material showing both flower- and needle-like morphologies. (b) SEM image of Cu2V4O16-2D showing the crystalline edge of the needle-like crystals. (c) Flower-like morphological phase of Cu2V4O16-2D which is present in the bulk product along with the needle-like crystal; one flower-like morphology grown around the needle-like crystal. (d) Zoomed view of one flower-like morphology showing the aggregation of flakes.

(d) Zoomed view of one flower-like morphology showing the aggregation of flakes.

elements.content: (a) Comparison of the experimental PXRD pattern of as-synthesized Cu2V4O16-2D (top) with the simulated one from its single crystal structure (bottom). (b) IR-spectroscopy of Cu2V4O16-2D. The inset picture shows the thermal gravimetric analysis curve for Cu2V4O16-2D. (c) CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherm for Cu2V4O16-2D at 298 K below 1.0 bar. [Filled circles are for adsorption, and empty circles are for desorption.] (d) Temperature variation in magnetization measured in a 500 Oe field following the ZFC and FC protocols; the inset picture shows the field dependence of magnetization at 3 K for Cu2V4O16-2D.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Comparison of the experimental PXRD pattern of as-synthesized Cu2V4O16-2D (top) with the simulated one from its single crystal structure (bottom). (b) IR-spectroscopy of Cu2V4O16-2D. The inset picture shows the thermal gravimetric analysis curve for Cu2V4O16-2D. (c) CO2 adsorption-desorption isotherm for Cu2V4O16-2D at 298 K below 1.0 bar. [Filled circles are for adsorption, and empty circles are for desorption.] (d) Temperature variation in magnetization measured in a 500 Oe field following the ZFC and FC protocols; the inset picture shows the field dependence of magnetization at 3 K for Cu2V4O16-2D.

elements.content: DC magnetization vs temperature measurements were performed for Cu 2 V4O16-2D at 500 Oe in both field cooled (FC) and zero field cooled (ZFC) modes. The temperature dependence of the ZFC and FC magnetization for Cu2V4O8-2D did not show any divergence in the measured temperature range (Figure d). The effective magnetic moment μeff vs T curve increases smoothly until 80 K and then shows a sharply increasing trend in μeff with decreasing temperature until the lowest measured temperature. At 300 K, the value of μeff is 1.3 μB/Cu atom, which is quite less than the theoretical calculated value for one Cu(II) ion (1.73 μB), indicating significant randomization of spins even in the applied field of 500 Oe (Figure S15 in the ; these values are plotted for two Cu(II) atoms located in a formula unit). However, at 3 K, the value of μeff increases slightly, up to 1.42 μB/Cu atoms, due to canting of spins due to the combined effect of weak antiferromagnetic interaction, external magnetic field, and thermal activation energy. The value of χT at 300 K is 0.81 emu mol–1 K, which decreases smoothly, reaching a minimum value at 80 K. Then, as temperature is further decreased, the χT curve increases very rapidly until the lowest measured temperature (Figure S16 in the ). The smooth decrease of the χT value below 300 K is a clear signature of an antiferromagnetic coupling between nearest neighboring Cu(II) atoms in the structure. The Curie–Weiss fit of the inverse molar susceptibility χ–1 in the 3–300 K range yields θ = −33 K. The negative sign of the Weiss constant further suggests the presence of antiferromagnetic interaction between near neighbors (Figure S17 in the ). The field dependent magnetization hysteresis loop measured at 3 K reveals a slight nonlinear response where at 7 T the magnetization value reaches a value of 8.9 emu/g (Figure d).
elements.clean_text: DC magnetization vs temperature measurements were performed for Cu 2 V4O16-2D at 500 Oe in both field cooled (FC) and zero field cooled (ZFC) modes. The temperature dependence of the ZFC and FC magnetization for Cu2V4O8-2D did not show any divergence in the measured temperature range (Figure d). The effective magnetic moment μeff vs T curve increases smoothly until 80 K and then shows a sharply increasing trend in μeff with decreasing temperature until the lowest measured temperature. At 300 K, the value of μeff is 1.3 μB/Cu atom, which is quite less than the theoretical calculated value for one Cu(II) ion (1.73 μB), indicating significant randomization of spins even in the applied field of 500 Oe (Figure S15 in the ; these values are plotted for two Cu(II) atoms located in a formula unit). However, at 3 K, the value of μeff increases slightly, up to 1.42 μB/Cu atoms, due to canting of spins due to the combined effect of weak antiferromagnetic interaction, external magnetic field, and thermal activation energy. The value of χT at 300 K is 0.81 emu mol-1 K, which decreases smoothly, reaching a minimum value at 80 K. Then, as temperature is further decreased, the χT curve increases very rapidly until the lowest measured temperature (Figure S16 in the ). The smooth decrease of the χT value below 300 K is a clear signature of an antiferromagnetic coupling between nearest neighboring Cu(II) atoms in the structure. The Curie-Weiss fit of the inverse molar susceptibility χ-1 in the 3-300 K range yields θ = -33 K. The negative sign of the Weiss constant further suggests the presence of antiferromagnetic interaction between near neighbors (Figure S17 in the ). The field dependent magnetization hysteresis loop measured at 3 K reveals a slight nonlinear response where at 7 T the magnetization value reaches a value of 8.9 emu/g (Figure d).

elements.content: In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized a two-dimensional Cu(II) connected and rarely observed vanadium cubane based MOF. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of a transitional metal connected V4O16 cubane based metal organic architecture. The SEM image of the bulk material shows two types of morphologies: needle-like crystals (major) and flower type aggregation (minor). However, IR spectroscopy, PXRD, and EA data of the bulk material show the presence of only one phase. As a result, one could incur that the flower type of morphology could be an intermediate stage of crystallization which is en route toward the needle-like crystal. We also studied H2 and CO2 adsorption on Cu2V4O16-2D, which is a rare effort in POM chemistry.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized a two-dimensional Cu(II) connected and rarely observed vanadium cubane based MOF. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of a transitional metal connected V4O16 cubane based metal organic architecture. The SEM image of the bulk material shows two types of morphologies: needle-like crystals (major) and flower type aggregation (minor). However, IR spectroscopy, PXRD, and EA data of the bulk material show the presence of only one phase. As a result, one could incur that the flower type of morphology could be an intermediate stage of crystallization which is en route toward the needle-like crystal. We also studied H2 and CO2 adsorption on Cu2V4O16-2D, which is a rare effort in POM chemistry.

elements.content: Description of experimental details, including synthetic methods; crystallography; supplementary figures, including TGA and powder XRD profiles; tables of crystallographic data,; and CIF files and thermal ellipsoids for the MOF reported in this paper. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content:
We have performed a detailed study of different types of polyoxovanadate reported in the literature based on CSD version 5.32, November 2010 in Table S4 in the .

This type of M4 cubane containing other metals, such as Li, Na, K, Cr, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, etc., is already reported in the literature.
elements.clean_text:

cln_elements.content: (a) Schematic and ball–stick models of the V4O16 unit. (b) One V4O16 cubane connected to four phosphates and four Cu(II) square-pyramid units. (c) 2-D arrangement of Cu2V4O16-2D, where one V4-cubane is connected to the next V4-cubane via one phsophate group through the a-axis and via two phosphates and two Cu(II) units through the b-axis. (d) Interdigitation of 2-D sheets of Cu2V4O16-2D via the phenanthroline ring in the ac-plane. [Color code: black, C; green, Cu; red, O; blue, N; yellow, P; dark yellow, V.]

cln_elements.content: (a) SEM image of the bulk material showing both flower- and needle-like morphologies. (b) SEM image of Cu2V4O16-2D showing the crystalline edge of the needle-like crystals. (c) Flower-like morphological phase of Cu2V4O16-2D which is present in the bulk product along with the needle-like crystal; one flower-like morphology grown around the needle-like crystal. (d) Zoomed view of one flower-like morphology showing the aggregation of flakes.

cln_elements.content: (a) Comparison of the experimental PXRD pattern of as-synthesized Cu2V4O16-2D (top) with the simulated one from its single crystal structure (bottom). (b) IR-spectroscopy of Cu2V4O16-2D. The inset picture shows the thermal gravimetric analysis curve for Cu2V4O16-2D. (c) CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherm for Cu2V4O16-2D at 298 K below 1.0 bar. [Filled circles are for adsorption, and empty circles are for desorption.] (d) Temperature variation in magnetization measured in a 500 Oe field following the ZFC and FC protocols; the inset picture shows the field dependence of magnetization at 3 K for Cu2V4O16-2D.

[Filled circles are for adsorption, and empty circles are for desorption.] (d) Temperature variation in magnetization measured in a 500 Oe field following the ZFC and FC protocols; the inset picture shows the field dependence of magnetization at 3 K for Cu2V4O16-2D.

metadata.title:
Solid Phase Morphological
Diversity of a Rare Vanadium
Cubane (V4O16) Based Metal Organic Framework
